@UniversalStandard\xc2\xa0treats all women equally when it comes to access to fashion.

Founders Alexandra Waldman and Polina Veksler say that across the industry, true inclusivity is long overdue.

All of the company\xe2\x80\x99s styles are available in sizes 00 to 40 \xe2\x80\x94 and don\xe2\x80\x99t call any part of that range \xe2\x80\x9cspecial sizing.\xe2\x80\x9d Veksler and Waldman reiterate again and again that there should be nothing special about the industry making clothes available to all women, regardless of body type, and that the designs of those clothes should reflect current styles.

\xe2\x80\x9cIf you are someone who has everything available from every brand, you can afford to say, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to buy from this brand because I care about the environment, and I have all these choices where I can buy the things that I want that cater to those personal beliefs.\xe2\x80\x99 If you are someone who is buying from a handful of brands, most of which are focused on probably the lowest price possible, which usually means the worst possible consequence for the environment, then you are constantly compromising, whether you like it or not.\xe2\x80\x9d

Universal Standard wants to chip away at that compromise. Conscious of the goal of a circular economy, Waldman and Veksler became eager to participate on a scale suited to their young company. A recycling program dovetailed nicely with US\xe2\x80\x99 ethos of providing all women the opportunity to buy high-quality clothes that last. The women came up with Reset, Recycle, Refresh, launched in September in partnership with recycling company Marimole.

Such good-citizenship manifestations make sense from a company that considers itself \xe2\x80\x9cthe world\xe2\x80\x99s most inclusive fashion brand.\xe2\x80\x9d
